snippet: The Los Angeles Times, which became the nation's largest metropolitan daily last year through its aggressive expansion efforts, plans to stop selling papers in a large part of central California and in neighboring states.   Executives of The Los A...
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Times, which became the nation's largest metropolitan daily last year through its aggressive expansion efforts, plans to stop selling papers in a large part of central California and in neighboring states. Executives of The Los Angeles Times, which has a weekday circulation of 1.2 million, said they decided to eliminate home-delivery and newsstand sales in the mostly rural area between Bakersfield and Fresno because of the weakened California economy.

headline.main: Los Angeles Times to Drop Some Readers

byline.original: Special to The New York Times
